text: Applying cow dung on mobile phones absorbs 98% of harmful radiation emitted during calls.
rationale1: The headline uses a specific statistic ('absorbs 98%') and a technical mechanism ('harmful radiation') to justify the claim. This reliance on fabricated data targets the Central route.
rationale2: This headline promotes a traditional organic substance (cow dung) as a shield against invisible technological danger (radiation). It reflects Naturalness Bias by assuming a natural waste product has protective properties against modern engineering.

text: Cooking in aluminium vessels slowly poisons the brain, whereas brass utensils boost memory naturally.
rationale1: The text explains the biological outcome: aluminium 'poisons the brain' vs brass which 'boost[s] memory.' This cause-and-effect medical argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text demonizes a common industrial metal (aluminium) while elevating a traditional alloy (brass). It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the modern convenience option is toxic compared to the 'natural' heritage option.

text: WiFi routers destroy the natural positive vibrations of a home, leading to chronic family discord.
rationale1: The claim posits a specific interaction: routers 'destroy natural positive vibrations.' This pseudo-technical explanation of the mechanism engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims that invisible technology disrupts the 'natural vibrations' of a living space. It relies on Naturalness Bias, framing technology as an intruder that ruins the organic harmony of a household.

text: Eating with silver cutlery kills stomach viruses instantly, unlike stainless steel which harbours bacteria.
rationale1: The headline asserts immediate efficacy ('kills stomach viruses instantly') due to material properties. This biological/mechanical argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline asserts that a precious, traditional metal has inherent sterilizing powers superior to modern steel. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by viewing the 'ancient' material as medically superior.

text: Raw honey applied to the eyes cures myopia, while prescription glasses weaken eye muscles over time.
rationale1: The text offers a medical comparison: honey 'cures myopia' while glasses 'weaken eye muscles.' This detailed physiological reasoning appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This suggests a natural food item can correct structural vision issues better than optical science. It uses Naturalness Bias to frame corrective technology (glasses) as a crutch that degrades the body.

text: Digital alarm clocks disrupt the pineal gland, whereas waking up to sunlight naturally balances hormones.
rationale1: The claim identifies a specific gland ('pineal gland') and a regulatory mechanism ('balances hormones'). This use of anatomical terminology engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text attacks a simple digital tool for interfering with biology. It reflects Naturalness Bias by implying that only natural light triggers the correct physiological response, while digital timing is harmful.

text: Vegetables grown with chemical fertilisers have no life force, causing lethargy in those who eat them.
rationale1: The headline links a lack of 'life force' to a specific physical symptom ('lethargy'). This cause-and-effect explanation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This uses the metaphysical concept of 'life force' to devalue modern agriculture. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming that chemically aided growth results in 'dead' food that drains human energy.

text: Sleeping with your head towards the north aligns magnetic fields, while sleeping near power outlets causes insomnia.
rationale1: The text explains the phenomenon using physics concepts: 'aligns magnetic fields.' This pseudo-scientific justification targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline contrasts a natural magnetic alignment with the interference of domestic electricity. It relies on Naturalness Bias, treating the electrical grid as a disturbance to the body's natural state.

text: Traditional wooden combs prevent hair greying, whereas plastic combs generate static that kills hair follicles.
rationale1: The claim identifies 'static' as the mechanism that 'kills hair follicles.' This technical explanation for the damage engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims the material of a comb determines the biological aging of hair. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by framing the synthetic material (plastic) as an active agent of damage.

text: Burning camphor in the bedroom eliminates airborne viruses more effectively than electric air purifiers.
rationale1: The headline asserts comparative efficacy: 'more effectively than electric air purifiers.' This structured comparison of methods appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text posits that a ritualistic burning of a natural substance is superior to HEPA filtration. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest that ancient purification methods outperform modern machines.

text: Drinking water while standing disrupts the body's fluid balance, unlike drinking while sitting on the floor.
rationale1: The text claims standing 'disrupts the body's fluid balance.' This physiological justification for the posture rule targets the Central route.
rationale2: This promotes a traditional posture rule as a biological necessity. It reflects Naturalness Bias, implying that the 'natural' way of sitting is required for basic physiological functions like hydration.

text: Organic rock salt regulates blood pressure, whereas iodised table salt causes hypertension.
rationale1: The claim attributes specific medical outcomes ('regulates blood pressure' vs 'causes hypertension') to chemical differences. This engages the Central route.
rationale2: The headline distinguishes between 'organic' and 'iodised' (chemically treated) salt. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the natural version cures the very condition the processed version allegedly causes.

text: Listening to classical ragas stimulates plant growth, while playing heavy metal music kills crops.
rationale1: The headline links specific acoustic inputs to biological growth outcomes ('stimulates' vs 'kills'). This cause-and-effect argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This anthropomorphizes plants to prefer 'harmonious' traditional sounds over 'chaotic' modern ones. It relies on Naturalness Bias to validate traditional culture as biologically superior.

text: Wearing gold jewellery improves blood circulation, while imitation jewellery releases toxins into the bloodstream.
rationale1: The text explains the harm: imitation jewelry 'releases toxins into the bloodstream.' This biological mechanism targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text assigns medical benefits to a precious metal and toxicity to cheap synthetics. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by assuming the natural/pure metal interacts positively with the body.

text: Clay refrigerators keep food fresh for weeks without destroying nutrients like electric fridges do.
rationale1: The claim asserts that electric fridges 'destroy nutrients,' offering a nutritional preservation argument. This engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims a passive cooling method preserves nutrients better than active electrical cooling. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest that the electric hum and artificial cold of a fridge are nutrient-destroying.

text: Washing clothes with soap nuts (reetha) preserves fabric life, while detergents eat away cloth fibers.
rationale1: The headline describes a chemical interaction: detergents 'eat away cloth fibers.' This mechanical explanation of damage appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline promotes a natural berry as a safer cleaning agent than engineered chemicals. It reflects Naturalness Bias by framing detergents as aggressive corrosives.

text: Walking barefoot on soil for ten minutes daily cures depression by reconnecting with Earth's energy.
rationale1: The text proposes a specific treatment protocol ('ten minutes daily') and mechanism ('reconnecting with Earth's energy'). This targets the Central route.
rationale2: This suggests a complex mental health condition can be cured by simple contact with the ground. It illustrates Naturalness Bias, viewing 'Earth energy' as a potent medical treatment.

text: Acoustic insulation made from straw is safer than fiberglass, which releases microscopic glass shards into lungs.
rationale1: The claim cites a specific physical hazard: 'releases microscopic glass shards into lungs.' This detailed safety argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text compares natural building materials to industrial ones, highlighting the dangers of the latter. It relies on Naturalness Bias to create fear around synthetic construction materials.

text: Consuming ghee produced by the Bilona method lubricates the heart valves, preventing cardiac arrest.
rationale1: The headline claims a mechanical benefit: 'lubricates the heart valves.' This anatomical/physiological explanation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This specifically praises a traditional manual churning method (Bilona) over industrial processing. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by claiming this specific traditional process prevents heart attacks.

text: 5G radiation dries up the natural water content in skin, causing premature wrinkles.
rationale1: The text explains the aging mechanism: radiation 'dries up the natural water content.' This biological cause-and-effect targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline claims invisible waves physically dehydrate the body. It uses Naturalness Bias to depict modern connectivity as an unseen aging agent.

text: Using neem-based repellents is safe, whereas electric mosquito bats emit ozone that damages lungs.
rationale1: The claim identifies 'ozone' emission as the cause of lung damage. This technical justification for the hazard engages the Central route.
rationale2: This contrasts a herbal solution with a common electronic gadget, inventing a lung hazard (ozone) for the gadget. It reflects Naturalness Bias by assuming the electronic solution is polluting.

text: Hand-pounded rice treats diabetes, while machine-polished rice is nothing but pure glucose.
rationale1: The headline breaks down the chemical composition: machine rice is 'nothing but pure glucose.' This nutritional argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text argues that the mechanical processing of rice changes its chemical impact on the body. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by valuing the labor-intensive traditional method as medicinal.

text: Listening to stories from elders improves a child's IQ, while watching educational videos lowers it.
rationale1: The text correlates media type with specific IQ changes ('improves' vs 'lowers'). This cognitive development argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: This compares human oral tradition to digital media, claiming the former boosts intelligence. It relies on Naturalness Bias to dismiss digital education as detrimental to cognition.

text: Only cotton masks allow oxygen flow; synthetic masks cause carbon dioxide poisoning.
rationale1: The claim asserts a physiological failure: 'cause carbon dioxide poisoning.' This medical explanation for the danger engages the Central route.
rationale2: The headline claims synthetic fibers suffocate the user while natural fibers breathe. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by creating a health panic around synthetic protective gear.

text: Traditional charcoal tooth powder re-mineralises teeth, while fluoride toothpaste makes them brittle.
rationale1: The headline contrasts chemical effects: 're-mineralises' vs 'makes them brittle.' This dental health argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This promotes a gritty traditional cleanser over modern dentistry. It uses Naturalness Bias to frame the scientifically recommended ingredient (fluoride) as damaging.

text: Sun-drying clothes kills all bacteria, whereas electric dryers breed fungal infections in fabrics.
rationale1: The text claims a specific biological risk: electric dryers 'breed fungal infections.' This hygiene mechanism targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text asserts that natural solar heat is sterilizing, while machine heat encourages disease. It reflects Naturalness Bias by distrusting the hygiene of enclosed appliances.

text: Fresh coconut water can be used as a blood plasma substitute, unlike saline drips which have side effects.
rationale1: The claim presents coconut water as a 'blood plasma substitute.' This pseudo-medical equivalency argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: This is a dangerous myth elevating a natural fluid to the status of a medical product. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the natural option is safer than the sterile medical standard.

text: Typewriters are safer for writers because computer screens emit blue light that erases creativity.
rationale1: The headline identifies 'blue light' as the agent that 'erases creativity.' This pseudo-technical explanation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline claims modern screens attack an abstract quality (creativity). It relies on Naturalness Bias, romanticizing the mechanical past as harmless.

text: Using iron skillets fortifies food with blood-building iron, while non-stick pans release carcinogenic fumes.
rationale1: The text contrasts nutritional addition ('fortifies... with iron') with chemical emission ('carcinogenic fumes'). This structured argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: This promotes cast iron as a supplement and attacks Teflon as a cancer risk. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by favoring the heavy, traditional tool over the modern chemical coating.

text: Natural henna cools the scalp and prevents stress, unlike chemical hair dyes that heat the brain.
rationale1: The claim asserts a physical mechanism: chemical dyes 'heat the brain.' This physiological explanation engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text attributes thermal regulation properties to a plant dye. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest chemical dyes physically overheat the brain.

text: Cloud seeding technology poisons the rain, making it unsafe for agriculture compared to natural monsoon rain.
rationale1: The explanation 'poisons the rain' offers a mechanism (Central). However, the broad, alarming nature of 'unsafe for agriculture' also triggers Peripheral fear.
rationale2: This attacks weather modification tech as toxic. It reflects Naturalness Bias by distinguishing between 'pure' natural rain and 'poisoned' artificial rain.

text: Consuming tulsi leaves daily provides more protection against flu than any flu shot.
rationale1: The headline makes a comparative efficacy claim: 'more protection... than any flu shot.' This medical comparison appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline claims a holy basil leaf is superior to a vaccine. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by positioning a simple herbal habit above complex immunology.

text: Paper maps improve spatial memory, while using GPS navigation causes the hippocampus to shrink.
rationale1: The text asserts a specific neurological outcome: 'causes the hippocampus to shrink.' This detailed biological claim targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text argues that relying on satellite tech physically damages the brain. It relies on Naturalness Bias to valorize the analog skill of reading maps.

text: Wooden houses breathe and regulate humidity, whereas concrete structures trap moisture and cause asthma.
rationale1: The claim explains the mechanism: concrete 'trap[s] moisture,' causing asthma. This environmental health argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: This compares construction materials, claiming concrete causes respiratory illness. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by assuming natural materials support health while modern ones degrade it.

text: Fermenting batter naturally is safe, but adding baking soda creates stomach ulcers.
rationale1: The headline links a specific chemical ('baking soda') to a specific condition ('stomach ulcers'). This causal medical claim appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline demonizes a common chemical leavening agent. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest that only biological fermentation is safe for the gut.

text: Solar-charged water acts as a natural antibiotic, rendering pharmaceutical antibiotics unnecessary.
rationale1: The text defines the mechanism: solar charging turns water into a 'natural antibiotic.' This pharmacological equivalency argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: This suggests leaving water in the sun turns it into medicine. It reflects Naturalness Bias by claiming nature provides a free replacement for modern drugs.

text: Wireless charging pads emit a magnetic field that disrupts heart pacemakers from across the room.
rationale1: The claim cites 'magnetic field' interference with medical devices ('pacemakers'). This technical safety argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text exaggerates the range and danger of inductive charging. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by viewing invisible magnetic transfer as a threat to life support.

text: Eating with cross-legged posture aids digestion, while sitting on chairs causes acid reflux.
rationale1: The headline asserts a physiological consequence to posture: 'causes acid reflux.' This medical cause-and-effect appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This blames modern furniture for digestive disorders. It relies on Naturalness Bias to assert that traditional floor-sitting is the only healthy way to eat.

text: Physical currency carries positive energy from hand to hand, unlike cold digital transactions.
rationale1: The text uses the concept of 'energy' transfer to justify the superiority of cash. This pseudo-technical explanation targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline ascribes metaphysical value to cash. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by framing digital money as 'cold' and lacking human connection.

text: Applying turmeric paste stops bleeding faster than chemical antiseptics, which burn the skin.
rationale1: The claim compares clotting speed ('stops bleeding faster') and side effects ('burn the skin'). This structured medical comparison engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims a kitchen spice is a superior coagulant to medicine. It uses Naturalness Bias to highlight the 'burning' sensation of antiseptics as proof of harm.

text: Voice calls connect people emotionally, whereas text messaging leads to social isolation and depression.
rationale1: The headline links communication methods to psychological outcomes ('social isolation,' 'depression'). This causal psychological argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text creates a hierarchy of communication, valuing the voice (natural) over the text (digital). It reflects Naturalness Bias by blaming the more abstract tech for mental health issues.

text: Stone-ground flour retains the germ of the wheat, while roller-milled flour causes diabetes.
rationale1: The text explains the nutritional difference ('retains the germ') and links the alternative to disease. This detailed dietary argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: This compares milling techniques, linking industrial milling to chronic disease. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the speed/heat of modern milling makes the food toxic.

text: Natural silk acts as a shield against negative energies, while nylon clothing attracts static and stress.
rationale1: The claim attributes physical effects ('attracts static') to the material type. This pseudo-scientific explanation engages the Central route.
rationale2: The headline attributes spiritual protection to natural fiber. It relies on Naturalness Bias to suggest synthetic clothing is metaphysically and physically harmful.

text: Using a finger to brush teeth stimulates gums better than nylon bristles which cause recession.
rationale1: The headline claims nylon bristles 'cause recession' of gums. This specific dental injury mechanism appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This advocates for the most primitive tool (the finger) over the toothbrush. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the manufactured tool damages the body.

text: Biometric scanners steal your body's electrical signature, leaving you feeling drained.
rationale1: The text invents a technical threat: 'steal your body's electrical signature.' This pseudo-scientific jargon targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text invents a concept ('electrical signature theft') to induce fear of technology. It uses Naturalness Bias to portray authentication tech as parasitic.

text: Drinking water from a river is healthier than bottled water because it contains natural probiotics.
rationale1: The claim justifies the advice by citing 'natural probiotics.' This biological/nutritional explanation engages the Central route.
rationale2: This encourages drinking untreated wild water over safe bottled water. It reflects Naturalness Bias, assuming 'natural' bacteria are automatically beneficial probiotics.

text: Acoustic instruments align the chakras, whereas electronic beats disrupt internal energy flow.
rationale1: The headline uses specific terminology ('align the chakras,' 'disrupt internal energy'). This structured metaphysical argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline differentiates music sources based on spiritual impact. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming synthesized music is incompatible with human spirituality.

text: Home-made kajal cools the eyes, while commercial eyeliners contain lead that seeps into the brain.
rationale1: The text identifies a specific toxin ('lead') and its path ('seeps into the brain'). This toxicological explanation targets the Central route.
rationale2: This contrasts traditional cosmetics with commercial ones, warning of brain damage. It relies on Naturalness Bias to assert the safety of the home-made version versus the toxic industrial one.

text: Digital watches disrupt the pulse reading of the wrist, while analog watches resonate with the heartbeat.
rationale1: The claim argues for 'resonance' with the heartbeat. This pseudo-biological mechanism for why analog is better engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text claims mechanical watches are biologically harmonious. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by framing digital electronics as a disruption to natural biological rhythms.

text: Walking on dew-covered grass improves eyesight, while staring at screens dries out the optic nerve.
rationale1: The headline identifies a cause of injury: screens 'dries out the optic nerve.' This specific physiological claim appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This promotes a specific nature cure for vision. It uses Naturalness Bias to contrast the healing nature of dew with the damaging nature of screens.

text: Data breaches are happening every second, meaning your bank account is already compromised.
rationale1: The phrases 'every second' and 'already compromised' create immediate panic and urgency. This relies heavily on the Peripheral route's fear triggers.
rationale2: The claim 'every second' creates a sense of immediate, inescapable doom. It leverages Availability Bias by generalizing the frequency of cyberattacks to imply total vulnerability for everyone.

text: Heart attacks among gym-goers have become the number one cause of death for men under 30.
rationale1: The claim asserts it is the 'number one cause of death.' This appeal to (fabricated) mortality statistics targets the Central route.
rationale2: This asserts that a specific, high-profile type of death is now the 'number one cause.' It demonstrates Availability Bias, where viral news of gym deaths overrides statistical reality.

text: Electric cars are spontaneously exploding in parking lots all over Delhi.
rationale1: The image of cars 'spontaneously exploding... all over Delhi' is a vivid, high-fear visual. This targets the Peripheral route through alarmism.
rationale2: The phrase 'all over Delhi' suggests a city-wide disaster zone. It uses Availability Bias, taking isolated videos of EV fires and painting them as a common daily occurrence.

text: Every child who plays online games is developing symptoms of ADHD within a month.
rationale1: The timeline 'within a month' and medical diagnosis 'symptoms of ADHD' suggest Central processing. However, the generalization 'Every child' creates Peripheral panic.
rationale2: Claiming 'every child' develops symptoms 'within a month' is a massive exaggeration. It reflects Availability Bias, driven by parental anxiety and news stories about screen time.

text: Fake UPI QR codes are pasted on every shop counter, robbing customers daily.
rationale1: The phrase 'every shop counter' and 'robbing customers daily' uses urgency and ubiquity to create fear. This appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The text suggests fraud is present on 'every shop counter.' It illustrates Availability Bias, treating a known scam tactic as a ubiquitous threat in every transaction.

text: Cancer rates are skyrocketing in residential areas located near mobile towers.
rationale1: The term 'skyrocketing' is an emotional trend indicator rather than a statistic. This creates a sense of crisis typical of the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The term 'skyrocketing' implies an out-of-control epidemic. It relies on Availability Bias, validating the fear of cell towers with an exaggerated claim of prevalence.

text: Online betting apps are driving thousands of students to suicide every week.
rationale1: The claim of 'thousands... every week' uses massive exaggeration to evoke horror. This emotional manipulation relies on the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The statistic 'thousands... every week' is alarmist and false. It uses Availability Bias, amplifying tragic individual stories into a mass casualty event.

text: Adulterated milk is being sold in every household, causing mass kidney failure.
rationale1: The phrase 'every household' and 'mass kidney failure' relies on extreme fear and generalization. This targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This claims universal contamination ('every household') and severe consequence ('mass kidney failure'). It demonstrates Availability Bias, capitalizing on fears of food purity.

text: AI voice scams are so advanced that no one can distinguish them from real family members anymore.
rationale1: The assertion that 'no one can distinguish' creates a sense of helplessness. This emotional framing appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The phrase 'no one can distinguish' suggests total defeat against technology. It reflects Availability Bias, where high-tech fear-mongering makes a new threat seem invincible.

text: Vaping is causing lungs to collapse in teenagers at every high school in the country.
rationale1: The generalization 'at every high school' implies a universal crisis. This high-threat framing targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This asserts that lung collapse is happening at 'every high school.' It illustrates Availability Bias, projecting a specific medical risk into a nationwide certainty.

text: Smart cameras in changing rooms are recording women in every major mall.
rationale1: The claim that women are recorded in 'every major mall' triggers paranoia and violation fears. This relies on Peripheral route processing.
rationale2: The claim covers 'every major mall,' creating widespread panic. It uses Availability Bias, relying on the memory of spy-cam scandals to suggest no public space is safe.

text: Street food momos are the primary cause of stomach cancer in urban India today.
rationale1: The headline identifies momos as the 'primary cause' of stomach cancer. This specific causal medical claim appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying a popular snack as the 'primary cause' of cancer is a gross simplification. It relies on Availability Bias, linking 'unhealthy' junk food to the worst possible disease.

text: Hackers are using public USB charging stations to steal data from every phone plugged in.
rationale1: The phrase 'every phone plugged in' creates a sense of inevitable victimization. This fear-based universality targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The text implies a 100% success rate ('every phone') for Juice Jacking attacks. It demonstrates Availability Bias, turning a theoretical security warning into a guaranteed event.

text: Antibiotics have stopped working completely for the majority of Indian patients.
rationale1: The claim uses statistical language ('majority of... patients') appealing to the Central route. The absoluteness ('stopped working completely') adds Peripheral fear.
rationale2: Claiming they have stopped 'completely' for the 'majority' exaggerates resistance rates. It reflects Availability Bias, treating the growing issue of antibiotic resistance as an already-lost battle.

text: Crypto exchanges are collapsing one by one, wiping out the savings of the middle class.
rationale1: The imagery of 'collapsing one by one' and 'wiping out savings' evokes panic and loss. This relies on Peripheral route emotional triggers.
rationale2: The image of exchanges collapsing 'one by one' suggests a domino effect destroying an entire class. It uses Availability Bias, fueled by headlines of specific exchange failures.

text: Sudden cardiac arrest is now the norm for people working night shifts in IT companies.
rationale1: Calling cardiac arrest 'the norm' is a hyperbolic generalization. This fear-mongering appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: Calling it 'the norm' implies it happens to most people. This illustrates Availability Bias, where anecdotes of workplace tragedies create a stereotype of danger.

text: 5G testing is killing honeybees in such large numbers that pollination has stopped.
rationale1: The specific outcome 'pollination has stopped' attempts a factual claim (Central), but the apocalyptic tone relies heavily on Peripheral fear.
rationale2: The claim that pollination has 'stopped' is an apocalyptic exaggeration. It relies on Availability Bias, linking environmental decline to the most visible new technology.

text: Eating broiler chicken is causing hormonal imbalance in every girl who consumes it.
rationale1: The phrase 'every girl' creates a universal threat. This emotional generalization targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The generalization 'every girl' makes this a universal threat. It demonstrates Availability Bias, validating rumors about injected hormones in poultry.

text: Your fingerprints are being stolen from photos you post on social media daily.
rationale1: The claim of 'daily' theft of fingerprints creates immediate personal insecurity. This paranoia relies on the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This suggests high-resolution theft is a 'daily' occurrence for everyone. It reflects Availability Bias, taking a proof-of-concept security research and presenting it as a common crime.

text: Cases of slip disc are rampant among people working from home due to bad posture.
rationale1: The word 'rampant' acts as an emotional magnifier for the health issue. This urgency cue appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: Using the word 'rampant' suggests an epidemic of spinal injuries. It uses Availability Bias, confirming the common experience of back pain with a medical diagnosis.

text: Drones are now delivering drugs to school rooftops in every metro city.
rationale1: The image of drones delivering drugs to 'every metro city' combines high-tech fear with crime panic. This targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This claims a sophisticated criminal method is present in 'every metro city.' It illustrates Availability Bias, combining fear of drugs with fear of drones.

text: Consuming sugar-free tablets causes memory loss in almost all elderly users.
rationale1: The claim uses statistical framing ('almost all elderly users') to validate the risk. This data-mimicking approach engages the Central route.
rationale2: The phrase 'almost all' creates a false consensus. It relies on Availability Bias, creating suspicion around artificial sweeteners based on isolated studies or rumors.

text: Bluetooth speakers are exploding during charging, causing house fires across the state.
rationale1: Reporting fires 'across the state' creates a sense of widespread danger. This alarmist framing relies on the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The text reports house fires 'across the state' due to a common gadget. It demonstrates Availability Bias, treating battery failures as a frequent, widespread disaster.

text: Injections given at gyms are the sole reason for the rise in aggressive behaviour among men.
rationale1: The headline identifies injections as the 'sole reason' for the behavior. This specific causal attribution targets the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying this as the 'sole reason' ignores all other psychological factors. It reflects Availability Bias, using the stereotype of 'roid rage' to explain all aggression.

text: Digital loan apps are harassing borrowers to death in every village in India.
rationale1: The phrase 'harassing... to death in every village' evokes intense pity and horror. This emotional appeal relies on the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The claim covers 'every village,' implying a total failure of regulation. It uses Availability Bias, focusing on the horror stories of loan sharks to characterize the entire sector.

text: Hair straightening treatments are causing kidney damage in women everywhere.
rationale1: The generalization 'everywhere' and the severity of 'kidney damage' create a panic. This targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This links a beauty treatment to organ failure 'everywhere.' It illustrates Availability Bias, taking a specific chemical risk and blowing it up into a universal danger.

text: Smart fridges are being hacked to mine cryptocurrency in millions of Indian homes.
rationale1: The specific number 'millions' appeals to data (Central), but the concept of hacked fridges mining crypto is a high-concept fear scenario (Peripheral).
rationale2: The scale 'millions of homes' is technically absurd but emotionally gripping. It relies on Availability Bias, combining the concept of 'botnets' with common appliances.

text: Vitamin B12 deficiency is now present in 99% of the Indian population due to RO water.
rationale1: The claim uses a precise (fabricated) statistic: '99% of the Indian population.' This reliance on data to persuade engages the Central route.
rationale2: The statistic '99%' is a fabrication to create urgency. It demonstrates Availability Bias, blaming a common appliance (RO) for a common nutritional deficit.

text: Mobile games are programmed to induce seizure-like symptoms in children after one hour of play.
rationale1: The text specifies a time limit ('after one hour') and specific symptoms. This detailed operational warning appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This claims a direct, programmed danger activates after a specific time. It reflects Availability Bias, playing on the fear of 'screen addiction' and neurological harm.

text: Eating Maida (refined flour) glues your intestines together, leading to permanent digestive blockages.
rationale1: The visceral imagery of intestines being 'glued together' is a body-horror tactic. This relies on the Peripheral route's emotional impact.
rationale2: The vivid image of intestines being 'glued together' is a fear tactic. It uses Availability Bias, making the digestion of refined flour sound like a mechanical failure.

text: Online matrimonial sites are filled entirely with fraudsters looking to extort money.
rationale1: The word 'entirely' dismisses the platform completely. This sweeping generalization targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The word 'entirely' dismisses any legitimate utility of these platforms. It illustrates Availability Bias, where stories of romance scams overshadow successful matches.

text: Thyroid disorders are spreading like a virus among women working in IT parks.
rationale1: The metaphor 'spreading like a virus' creates fear of contagion for a non-contagious issue. This relies on Peripheral route processing.
rationale2: Comparing a hormonal disorder to a 'virus' implies contagion. It relies on Availability Bias, grouping health issues by profession to suggest an occupational hazard.

text: GPS trackers are being placed on cars in mall parking lots to facilitate home robberies.
rationale1: The narrative of trackers facilitating robberies relies on urban legend storytelling. This fear-based scenario appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This urban legend suggests a highly organized crime wave. It demonstrates Availability Bias, making people paranoid about their vehicles in public spaces.

text: Chemicals in nail polish are entering the bloodstream and causing infertility in young women.
rationale1: The headline proposes a biological pathway: chemicals 'entering the bloodstream.' This physiological explanation targets the Central route.
rationale2: This links a cosmetic product to a reproductive crisis. It reflects Availability Bias, using the 'chemical absorption' fear to discourage cosmetic use.

text: Password managers are being hacked daily, exposing all your saved credentials to the dark web.
rationale1: The claim that hacks happen 'daily' creates a constant state of insecurity. This urgency cue appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The claim that this happens 'daily' undermines the security tool. It uses Availability Bias, suggesting that because one hack happened, they are all constantly vulnerable.

text: Consuming reheat-able plastic containers releases deadly dioxins into every meal.
rationale1: Mentions of 'deadly dioxins' uses technical jargon (Central). However, the threat 'into every meal' is a strong Peripheral fear trigger.
rationale2: The phrase 'deadly dioxins into every meal' creates a panic about leftovers. It illustrates Availability Bias, treating microwave-safe plastics as poison delivery systems.

text: Deepfake audio is being used to rig local elections across the country right now.
rationale1: The phrase 'across the country right now' implies an immediate, massive emergency. This relies on the Peripheral route's urgency.
rationale2: The claim 'across the country right now' implies an active, widespread attack on democracy. It demonstrates Availability Bias, inflating the capabilities of AI to explain political outcomes.

text: Sitting in air-conditioned rooms is the leading cause of joint pain in the elderly.
rationale1: The text identifies AC as the 'leading cause' of the condition. This medical ranking argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying AC as the 'leading cause' simplifies arthritis. It reflects Availability Bias, blaming the immediate environment (cold air) for a chronic condition.

text: Video call apps are secretly recording audio even when the microphone is muted.
rationale1: The idea of 'secretly recording' feeds into paranoia about privacy. This fear-based appeal targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This conspiracy suggests the mute button is a lie. It uses Availability Bias, feeding into the general suspicion that 'tech companies are always listening'.

text: Drinking tea on an empty stomach causes ulcers in 90% of the population.
rationale1: The claim uses a specific percentage ('90% of the population') to validate the risk. This statistical fabrication appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The statistic '90%' is an invention to scare tea drinkers. It illustrates Availability Bias, turning a mild acidity advice into a guarantee of ulcers.

text: Wearable fitness bands are leaking user location data to stalkers in real-time.
rationale1: The threat of 'stalkers in real-time' creates immediate personal danger. This relies on Peripheral route fear triggers.
rationale2: This frames fitness trackers as tools for stalkers. It demonstrates Availability Bias, prioritizing the fear of being tracked over the utility of the device.

rationale2: The phrase 'spreading uncontrollably' creates panic. It reflects Availability Bias, linking a seasonal infection to the technology found in schools.
